titleStmt.title: God appearing for the Parliament, in sundry late victories bestowed upon their forces, vvhich command and call for great praise and thanksgiving both from Parliament and people. Die Martis; 4. Martii, 1644. Ordered by the Commons House of Parliament, that Mr. Whitaker, Sir Thomas Widdrington, Mr. Rous, and Mr. Millington, do peruse all the letters that are come from Shrewsbury, Plimouth, Scarborough, Glocestershire, and Weymouth; and make a narrative out of them, of all Gods great and late mercies upon the Parliaments forces, to be printed, and read on the next day of publique thanksgiving. H: Elsynge, Cler. Parl. D. Com.

titleStmt.title: God appearing for the Parliament, in sundry late victories bestowed upon their forces, vvhich command and call for great praise and thanksgiving both from Parliament and people. Die Martis; 4. Martii, 1644. Ordered by the Commons House of Parliament, that Mr. Whitaker, Sir Thomas Widdrington, Mr. Rous, and Mr. Millington, do peruse all the letters that are come from Shrewsbury, Plimouth, Scarborough, Glocestershire, and Weymouth; and make a narrative out of them, of all Gods great and late mercies upon the Parliaments forces, to be printed, and read on the next day of publique thanksgiving. H: Elsynge, Cler. Parl. D. Com.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: God appearing for the Parliament, In Å¿undry late VICTORIES BeÅ¿towed upon their Forces, VVhich Command and call for great PraiÅ¿e and ThankÅ¿giving both from Parliament and People.

div.head: Die Martis; 4. Martii, 1644.
div.p: ORdered by the Commons HouÅ¿e of Parliament, That Mr. Whitaker, Sir Thomas Widdrington, Mr. Rous, and Mr. Millington, do peruÅ¿e all the Letters that are come from Shrewsbury, Plimouth, Scarborough, GloceÅ¿terÅ¿hire, and Weymouth; and make a Narrative out of them, of all Gods great and late Mercies upon the Parliaments Forces, to be Printed, and Read on the next day of Publique Thanksgiving.

closer.signed: H: ElÅ¿ynge, Cler. Parl. D. Com.

div.p: Printed at London for Edward Husbands. March 10. 1644.

div.head: The Preamble.

p.hi: THe Arme of the Lord daily brings mighty things to paÅ¿Å¿e: But there are Å¿ome things which he brings to paÅ¿Å¿e in Å¿uch a manner, that therein He makes His Arme bare and naked: He Å¿hewes his power and mighty working, with Å¿uch evidence and demonÅ¿tration that it Å¿trikes and Å¿hines like lightning, even into cloÅ¿ed eyes, and extorts an acknowledgement, That this is the power, and the very Arme of the Lord: thus is it when effects ariÅ¿e in a notable eminence, far above naturall cauÅ¿es, or contrary to them: When weakneÅ¿Å¿e performes the worke of extraordinary Å¿trength; and when notable Å¿trength, even Å¿trength unto preÅ¿umption, is turned into extraordinary weakneÅ¿Å¿e: When the bowes of the mighty are broken; and they that Å¿tumbled, are girt with Å¿trength.

div.p:
In this manner hath the Lords Arme of late appeared viÅ¿ibly in Å¿undry places; But moÅ¿t eminently in the WeÅ¿t, where with his own right Arme, he hath gotten HimÅ¿elf the Victory, and bestowed it upon us. The Towns of Weymouth and Melcomb are near by Å¿cituation, and one of them being dead, threatned death to the other; yea, the Enemy spake like the Egyptians of old (as it appears in intercepted Letters) I will purÅ¿ue, I will overtake,
I will divide the spoile, my lust Å¿hall be Å¿atisfied upon them: But thy right hand, O Lord, is become glorious, thy right hand hath daÅ¿hed the enemy in pieces; The living Town is kept alive, and by it God wrought a ReÅ¿urrection in that which was dead.
But to proceed according to the order of time, as firÅ¿t in that order (among Gods late gracious diÅ¿penÅ¿ations of Victory to the Parliaments forces) is preÅ¿ented to our view, and thankfulneÅ¿Å¿e.

body.head: An Extract out of Sir John Meldrums Letter written to the Speaker of the HouÅ¿e of Commons, dated from Scarborough 19. February, 1644.
body.p: IT hath pleaÅ¿ed God to give us happy Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e in the taking of the Town and Harbour of Scarborough, which otherwiÅ¿e might have proved a receptacle for Strangers, and a Å¿ubject for the longer continuance of this war; beÅ¿ides the inconveniences to the City of London, and other Southern parts by the interruption of the Coale Trade.

The Service was done after this manner: After that, their three men of war, which were appointed to Å¿coure along the Sands, were beaten and Å¿unke, and their Ordinance made unÅ¿erviceable: A Summons being Å¿ent, and an AnÅ¿wer returned, preÅ¿ent order was given, for falling upon their Works and the Town; which was done without any reÅ¿iÅ¿tance, untill they drew their Body within a Å¿trong Work about the Church, which if they had maintained as they might have done, they had puÅ¿led us; but upon view of the advancing of our foot, to cut their paÅ¿Å¿age betwixt the CaÅ¿tle, and the Church, they all retired within the CaÅ¿tle in great diÅ¿order: There was a Å¿trife betwixt the Officers and Souldiers, who Å¿hould Å¿hew moÅ¿t forwardneÅ¿Å¿e. Sir Hugh Cholmley did expect reliefe within four dayes.

body.head: Two Letters intercepted, which were written from Sir Hugh Cholmley, to two Commanders in the Kings Army.
body.p: SIr, we are cloÅ¿e blocked up into the CaÅ¿tle, and though no Forces could be Å¿ent to our reliefe, I admire I Å¿hould not be Å¿upplyed with thoÅ¿e accommodations which eÅ¿Å¿entially conduce to the defence of this place; I am bound in duty to let you know if we have not timely helpe the King will loÅ¿e his intereÅ¿t there, and yet I hope my Å¿elfe blameleÅ¿Å¿e. If it may advantage his affaires, for me to fall into the hands of thoÅ¿e which Å¿eeke my blood, I can willingly Å¿ubmit to it; but it will not be a preÅ¿ident to draw others to Å¿erve his MajeÅ¿ty with Å¿o little private ends, as I have done. The God Almighty direct and protect us all.

body.head: Meldrum is the active man here, and Commands in chiefe; he hath Å¿ome Å¿ix or Å¿even hundred of the Lord Fairfax his Foot, and a Regiment of Scots.
body.p: SIr, we are now blocked up cloÅ¿e into the CaÅ¿tle, divers of our Å¿ouldiers run away unto the Enemy, and it is to be feared, that the ill accommodation will daily decreaÅ¿e our number; you know the ConÅ¿equence, and beleeve me it requires Å¿peedy Å¿upply, for reaÅ¿ons I cannot expreÅ¿Å¿e. I pray Å¿ignify where, or from whence I may hope for reliefe, and whether any expectance of Forces from the Queene, or Ireland, or probability of a good iÅ¿Å¿ue from the Treaty; of which particulars I deÅ¿ire to be Å¿atiÅ¿fied, that I may not be totally in ignorance, not that the fayling of any, or all theÅ¿e Å¿hall make me quit this truÅ¿t otherwiÅ¿e then becomes a Gentleman, and good Subject. Your Colonell Wharton Å¿alutes you; And I am your humble Servant.

postscript.p: Here is ten Collours of Scots I imagine, though not above eight hundred men of them; But Sir Iohn Meldrum hath Å¿ix or Å¿even hundred more of the Lord Fairfaxes Foot, and Commands in chiefe.

body.head: An Extract out of a Letter written from Captaine Pierce to Sir Io. Young, a member of the HouÅ¿e of Commons, 21. Feb. 1644.
body.p:
ON the eighteenth of February laÅ¿t, the Enemy having the night before made a worke upon the old worke at Mont-Stamford, with a very large Line both Å¿ides from the worke; the Sea-men in the morning fell on them, and tooke one halfe Moon, which was made at the Å¿outh end of the Line; but the enemies horÅ¿e comming upon them, forced them to retreat, but with no loÅ¿Å¿e on our Å¿ide, bleÅ¿Å¿ed be God; Upon which we were all commanded to Armes; Å¿everall Companies were drawn out to goe over, and two Troops of horÅ¿e; one being Å¿till quartered on that Å¿ide, to joyne with Å¿ome Sea-men taken on Å¿hore for that purpoÅ¿e, all (I thinke) conÅ¿iÅ¿ting of about five hundred, and all the reÅ¿t of the GarriÅ¿on were commanded to march out to face the enemy on the North-Å¿ide, and were drawne without our Line within Musket-Å¿hot of their worke under the Hill, the Hill befriending us, that they could not play much on us: All we did, was only Å¿ending out Å¿mall Parties to Å¿hoot, as if we intended to fall on, that Å¿o they might draw off Å¿ome of their forces from the other Å¿ide of the water, where our purpoÅ¿e was to fall on: and it Å¿eemes, they did draw off Å¿ome horÅ¿e; and about two of the Clock in the after-noone, our men fell upon Mont-Stamford, where the enemy powred out mighty vollies of Å¿hot, as I have Å¿eene or heard; but our men went on with that reÅ¿olution both horÅ¿e and foot, that within little more then halfe an houre we tooke the worke, routed the enemy both horÅ¿e and foot, purÅ¿ued them above a mile, hewing and cutting them. The names of them we tooke were Lieutenant Colonell Mohun, Lient. Col. of HorÅ¿e, Major Richard Heale, Baronet Heales brother, Captaine Maynard, (who had taken up Armes on our Å¿ide) Captaine Hill, Captaine AÅ¿ton, Captaine Huchins, Lieutenant Waring, Lieut. Inglett, Lieut. AÅ¿hford, Lieut. Manwaring, EnÅ¿igne HalÅ¿e, EnÅ¿igne BattiÅ¿hill, and of private men ninety three, in all one hundred and eight perÅ¿ons, with many more Armes. They alÅ¿o found there Å¿ome Barrells of Powder, and Pioneers tooles, and Å¿ome horÅ¿es, and had neare taken them all, but for the woods and encloÅ¿ures
neare adjoyning. This day we had a CounÅ¿ell of Warre, to try Å¿uch of them as had heretofore taken up Armes on our Å¿ide, and proceeded upon three of them, viz. Captaine Maynard, Lieutenant AÅ¿hford, and EnÅ¿igne BattiÅ¿hill, who are to be executed to morrow, and Å¿ome other common men will follow.

body.head: An Extract out of the Letters written from the Committees of Shrewsbury, to the Speaker of the HouÅ¿e of Commons, with the LiÅ¿t of the PriÅ¿oners.
body.p:
IT hath pleaÅ¿ed God miraculouÅ¿ly to deliver the Towne of Salop into our hands, with all the Commanders, Officers, and Souldiers therein; a LiÅ¿t of the chiefe of them we have Å¿ent incloÅ¿ed. Upon the two and twentieth of this Moneth we drew out of our GarriÅ¿ons of Wem, Moreton, and Stoke, two hundred and fifty HorÅ¿e, and the like number of Foot, Sir William Brereton having Å¿ent us two hundred and fifty Foot, and three hundred and fifty HorÅ¿e; which party by our order was Commanded by Lieutenant Colonell Rincking (in the MarÅ¿halling of this deÅ¿igne he deÅ¿erves much honour) and Captaine Wyllier, and MaÅ¿ter HuÅ¿on a MiniÅ¿ter, led on the Fire-lockes, with fifty Troopers, diÅ¿mounted under the Command of Lieutenant Bendebue; they led on their men with undaunted reÅ¿olutions, after whom followed three hundred and fifty Foot, which by Severne Å¿ide Å¿tormed the Towne, neare unto the CaÅ¿tle wall, and marched unto the Market-houÅ¿e, and there Å¿urpiÅ¿ed the maine Guard, and then Å¿ent a Party to Å¿ecure the CaÅ¿tle-forehead Gate, which was effected without much difficulty, and after a quarter of an houre, the Draw-bridge was let downe, and the Gate opened, where Colonell Mytton, Colonell Bowyer, and all the Gentlemen of this Committee with the HorÅ¿e entred, and immediatly became MaÅ¿ters of the Towne, within foure houres after the CaÅ¿tle was delivered upon quarter, for all but the IriÅ¿h to march to Ludlow, and then the Enemy delivered up a Å¿trong Out-work in Franckwell upon bare quarter for their lives: by twelve of the clock we became MaÅ¿ters of the CaÅ¿tle and Towne, wherein were taken many conÅ¿iderable PriÅ¿oners (whereof the names of many are yet unliÅ¿ted, by reaÅ¿on of the want of time to Å¿ecure them) good
Å¿tore of Ammunition, and great Å¿tore of Ordnance. It was our care to preÅ¿erve the Town from plundering, but the promiÅ¿es of a large reward would not Å¿atisfie the Å¿ouldiers. Our horÅ¿e the day before had a long march, they being Å¿ent to Å¿urprize Sir William Whitmore, and Sir Thomas Whitmore, his Å¿onne being a Parliament man, which was effected, and they brought Å¿afe to VVem. Sir, we Å¿hall not trouble you further, but to Å¿ubÅ¿cribe our Å¿elves

list.head: A LiÅ¿t of the PriÅ¿oners taken at Salop the 22. day of Febr. 1644.
list.item: Sir Michael E â¢ nely, Knight; And his brother.
Charles Smith, Edward Palmer, Matthew Wightwicke, Ancients.
Vincent Taylor, Thomas Dewe, Humphrey Davies, Richard Brayne, Sergeants.
Patrick Lawry an IriÅ¿hman, fourty nine other PriÅ¿oners.

div.head: Touching Weymouth.
div.p: BY the treachery of divers malignant Inhabitants of Weymonth and Melcomb-Regis, with the knowledge and conÅ¿ent of Å¿ome Gunners upon duty in the Forts, on the 9 of February, the Enemy from Portland was let in by Sea, into the north Fort; there being then no Parliament Å¿hips in the Road, and into the Chappell Fort by land: who Å¿eizing upon the Guard and Gunns, poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ed themÅ¿elves of both Forts about twelve at night.

Sir Lewis Dives was by the Å¿ame Confederates to be let into the Towne of Melcombe, the Malignants haveing combined together to let out our priÅ¿oners, kill the Major of the Regiment, and Å¿eize upon the Maine Guard: This Å¿urpriÅ¿all of Melcombe was prevented, the Allarm being received at Weymouth firÅ¿t.

The Plott and Plotters are every day more and more diÅ¿covered, divers of them (by a juÅ¿t vengeance from Heaven) have been Å¿ince Å¿laine, Å¿ome wounded and others impriÅ¿oned, and in a poÅ¿ture Å¿peedily to be hanged.

Wee endeavoured the recoverie of the Chappell Fort within an houre after it was Å¿urpriÅ¿ed, but it was Å¿o Å¿trengthned with the aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance of the town
Malignants that wee were put to a retreat and Major Francis Siddenham Å¿laine.

Being ignorant what number the enemy was of in the Forts, and certain of a thouÅ¿and at leaÅ¿t not many miles off in the field: we were forced to betake our Å¿elves to Melcombe onely, and to reÅ¿olve to Å¿tand upon a poÅ¿ture of deÅ¿ence as long as we were able.
All that weeke they played upon us with their Cannon, battered many of our houÅ¿es and fired Å¿ome.
February the 16. we took of their horÅ¿e about eightie and fortie five priÅ¿oners upon a rout.
Sir Lewis Dives Sir Thomas AuÅ¿tins and. Cleevelands horÅ¿e with Å¿ome foot lay againÅ¿t us to block us up on the other Å¿ide
The next week was Å¿pent in batteries as the former:
On Sabbath day morning February twenty third Gorings forces being joyned to thoÅ¿e before mentioned drew downe in a body and faced us.
The Å¿ame night they began to caÅ¿t up a worke about a furlong from the Towne, out of which we beat them on Munday morning, killedÅ¿ome of their men, and tooke all their working tooles.

body.head: An Extract of the Letter written from Captaine Batten, to the Speaker of the HouÅ¿e of Commons 28. Febr. 1644. from aboard his MajeÅ¿ties Ship called the Reformation in Weymouth Road.
body.p: SInce my laÅ¿t, thanks be to God, wee are in farre better condition then we were then; On the 25 of this moneth the Governour went out of Melcombe with a party of HorÅ¿e and Foot, the Enemy on Weymouth Å¿ide, drew out a party of HorÅ¿e and Foot to meet them, and Å¿o faced each other Å¿ometime; the Governour making an orderly retreat with his Forces into Melcombe (having drawne away great part of the enemy from their workes) let down the Drawbridge, fell over into Weymouth, Å¿tormed the Chappell Fort, and carryed it & all Weymouth, without the l â¢ Å¿Å¿e of one man, and tooke about 60. priÅ¿oners beÅ¿ides what were Å¿lain, with divers horÅ¿e that were in their Å¿tables.

The 26. and 27. dayes, We playd hard upon the Enemy, and they on us, both with great and Å¿mall Å¿hott, and the 27. at night a PriÅ¿oner of ours ran from them, who gave us notice, that they would Å¿torme the Towne that night, in all places that they could, which was performed accordingly; the Enemy getting within our Workes neere to Weymouth Bridge, but were gallantly repulÅ¿ed by our men, with the loÅ¿Å¿e of Å¿ome hundreds of the Enemy. The Governour himÅ¿elfe behaving himÅ¿elfe like a gallant man, as hee hath done in all the Å¿iege; The Enemy at length was beaten back into their Works.

The 28. about ten of the clocke, they having received
this great blow, (and I believe having Å¿ome notice of Sir William Wallers approach) drew out all their forces, and left all our Workes, with the Guns in them, as they found them, and Å¿o are gone in a very confuÅ¿ed manner, Å¿o that we now enjoy all our Workes, and both Townes as formerly.

We have not loÅ¿t ten men, in the loÅ¿ing and taking all theÅ¿e Workes, nor in all the time of the Siege; I have two of my own Company, one hath loÅ¿t a legg, and the other dangerouÅ¿ly wounded, and will hardly eÅ¿cape, and three of Captain Jordans men Å¿calded by a miÅ¿chance, by the fireing of Å¿ome powder: indeed the Sea-men have Å¿howne themÅ¿elves very brave men in all this buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e.

We have many priÅ¿oners on board, and in towne, beÅ¿ides 40. Å¿ent away, to morrow we Å¿hall Å¿horten the number, by hanging Å¿ome of the townÅ¿men, who are priÅ¿oners aboard us, and were the betrayers of the towne.

Within three houres after the Enemy had quitted our Workes, the Endeavour, a Å¿hip of Weymouth, of twelve peeces of Ordnance, laden with Salt, (and Å¿ome part of her belonging to Malignants, and was got cloÅ¿e under Portland CaÅ¿tle) cut her Cables, and came off to mee, although the CaÅ¿tle made Å¿even or eight Å¿hotts at her, Å¿o that God hath bleÅ¿t us both by Sea and Land, to him be the glory

SInce my laÅ¿t (perceiving the enemy Å¿ecure, a party of my horÅ¿e and theirs, having beene lately engaged, and foot on each Å¿ide to their aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance) I fell on with about a hundred and fifty musketiers in the middle of the day, regained Weymouth, and Chappell Fort, and tooke one Leivtenant Colonell, one Major, three Captains, three Leivtenants, and one hundered common men with Å¿tore of proviÅ¿ions which the enemy had newly got together, and all with the loÅ¿Å¿e of but one man of ours, this did Å¿o enrage the enemy that the Lord Goring would needs be revenged, and to that purpoÅ¿e advanced with his whole body on thurÅ¿day night, and fell upon us about midnight at Å¿everall places, but entred only one of our Barracadoes, whence our men wear beaten back, juÅ¿t as I came by, which perceiving, I got a freÅ¿h party, and heat them off, recovered that Fort, which was Captain Thornhills and killed and tooke Å¿ome of the enemy there; this night we gave them Å¿uch a bruÅ¿h, that Mr. Iames Framp â¢ on of Buckland, reported yeÅ¿terday that two of their regiments were Å¿poiled, beÅ¿ides what they left in the Street, and in the Sea, its reported eighty dead men were carryed into Week, upon which (perceiving it Å¿eemes no good to be done by them, in keeping longer on the north, which we valued not when we had the Chappell) they Å¿uddainly Å¿tole out yeÅ¿terday, and have left both Beneleff and the North Forts, without either burning the Corne, or HouÅ¿es, or Å¿poyling our Guns, which I admire. Thus miraculouÅ¿ly hath God wrought for us in preÅ¿erving this little diÅ¿advantagious place againÅ¿t the other Towne and Forts, and an Army, and which is more in giving us Å¿uch Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e, and at laÅ¿t the poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿sion of
all in the face of that Army which came to releive them; I hope (whatÅ¿oever we have Å¿uffered) that this will tame the Cavies, and hath (in detaining that body here which might have done miÅ¿cheife elÅ¿e where) much advantaged the publique; God bringing good out of evill, my Souldiers HorÅ¿e and Foot, have all had very hard Å¿ervice of it day and night, I Å¿hall entreat you to write to the Parliament, for Å¿omething for their encouragement, they have neither money, nor cloathes, and yet unwearied in this buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e. I have nothing elÅ¿e to adde but that I am.

body.head: An Extract of Collonel Siddenhams letter to the Committee of the the WeÅ¿t.
Dated. 1. March. 1644.
body.p:
HAveing now Å¿ome few houres of freedome, from thoÅ¿e continued Sallyes, Alarms, Fireings and batteries which almoÅ¿t theÅ¿e three weekes have kept me from the leaÅ¿t leaÅ¿ure to doe any thing, but attend the enemy. I thinke it my duty to give you an account of Gods miraculous diÅ¿penÅ¿ations towards us. All (as you have formerly received) beeing treacheronÅ¿ly deliver into the hand of the enemy except Melcombe. On tueÅ¿day laÅ¿t Feb. 25. the enemy having drawne out many of their foot to relieve a party of their horÅ¿e, being indanger to be ingaged
by a party of ours which I Å¿ent out to diÅ¿cover the enemy. I fell preÅ¿ently upon Weymouth, which Towne (together with the Chappell Fort) was in an houre regained; where wee tooke priÅ¿oners, one Lievtenant Collonel one Major, three Captains, and one hundred of inferior Officers and Common Souldiers, which Å¿o inraged the enemy that upon thurÅ¿day laÅ¿t about Midnight they furiouÅ¿ly Å¿tormed us at Å¿everall places of both Townes, out of all Weymouth we were not able to keep them, and therefore reÅ¿olved to make good Å¿o much of it as might let us, upon any occaÅ¿ion, too and from the Chappell Fort. The enemy came in great multitudes thorow the Streets and backeÅ¿ides at both ends of the Towne, and diÅ¿puted with us very hotly about three houres for that Å¿male part of it, which wee were willing to keepe. The Chappell Fort, and Melcombe beeing likewiÅ¿e Å¿tormed at the Å¿ame time from all which places God inabled us to repell them. In all this time they wounded but one of my men. What execution was done upon the enemy, I am not certaine they carrying off as many as they were able before day, amongÅ¿t whom (as the people of the Towne have Å¿ince informed me) were divers in Buffe-Coats, and Velvet-lackets they left much blood behind them in the Streets and Å¿laine men upon the place, they carryed (as it is reported) many wounded men into one Village a mile from the Towne. Upon Friday about 10 of the Clocke, they Å¿uddenly left (except plunder) all which they had formerly gained, quitted their Forts, and marched away in a body, lying now at a little diÅ¿tance but blocking us up Å¿till as before, what they meane to doe next I know not, but doe expect Å¿ome further deÅ¿igne upon us, for they are now Å¿ummoning in the Country at DorcheÅ¿ter from Å¿ixteene to Å¿ixty.

body.head: An Extract of Collonell Iohn Binghams letter Governor of Poole, to the Committee of the WeÅ¿t. dated the firÅ¿t of March, 1644.
body.p: AS Å¿oon as this moÅ¿t happy news came to my hand, which our great and good God hath freely don for us, in giving us thoÅ¿e unlookt for loÅ¿t Forts with Weymouth Towne, I have Å¿ent it you in a true coppy of the Governors, Collonell Siddenhams Letter to peruÅ¿e: He begs reliefe for his vahant tir'd men, I beÅ¿eech you to tender his caÅ¿e and beleeve they have been put upon much extreame hard duty.

My Lords and Gentlmen her's litle of man Å¿een in this, all is Gods great, free, and not to be forgotten mercy, in manifeÅ¿ting his power in their much weakneÅ¿Å¿e, with which very well agreeth the profeÅ¿Å¿ion of the Governor of Weymouth Collonell Syddenham himÅ¿elf in theÅ¿e words. God hath diÅ¿covered himÅ¿elfe very gratiouÅ¿ly unto us in Å¿everall acts of providence, which I would not have wanted the experience of for a world. My Lords I am your faithfull Å¿ervant.

postscript.p: There are in our Countrey now gotten into a body neere a thouÅ¿and Country men with Gunns and Clubbs, to reÅ¿iÅ¿t the French and IriÅ¿h amongÅ¿t the Cavalliers: We have Å¿ent eightie horÅ¿e to their deÅ¿ired aide

body.head: A true Coppy of a Letter intercepted written from Sir Lewis Dives, to the Earle of BriÅ¿toll.
DorcheÅ¿ter 26. of February. 1644.
body.p: THe Church Fort by a Å¿trange misfortune was Å¿urprized this night by the Enemy in Melcombe, but the principall Forts, where all our Ammunition and ProviÅ¿ion lies, wee Å¿till maintaine; Sir John Berkley is Å¿ent for hither by my Lord Goring, to draw his Forces hither to joyne with ours, he having Å¿et up his reÅ¿t for the taking both that and the Towne of Melcombe together, which by Gods aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance we doubt not to effect, Wallers Forces being Å¿o Å¿cattered by the withdrawing of EÅ¿sex his HorÅ¿e, and MancheÅ¿ters Foot from him, as he is not in a condition to advance towards us, and this newes was laÅ¿t night confirmed to us by Kell. Digby, who came from Oxford. I beÅ¿eech your LordÅ¿hip be pleaÅ¿ed to employ all your IntereÅ¿ts with Sir Richard Greenvile, to haÅ¿ten the Å¿ending of fifteene hundred Foot, or two thouÅ¿and HorÅ¿e at the leaÅ¿t towards us, to make good DevonÅ¿hire againÅ¿t the Forces about Taunton, and that we may be at a neere diÅ¿tance to joyne together if there be occaÅ¿ion, and he Å¿hall want no HorÅ¿e from us that he Å¿hall have need of: The buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e is of that importance, as little leÅ¿Å¿e then the Crowne depends upon it, Å¿o as we are confident he will not be wanting to us in this extremity, Å¿o ceaÅ¿ing your LordÅ¿hips further trouble, I remaine,

closer.dateline: To the Right Honourable, the Earle of BriÅ¿toll at Exeter.
closer.signed: Your LordÅ¿hips moÅ¿t humble Å¿ervant, LEVVIS DIVES.

body.head: Another Letter intercepted From Sir Lewis Dives, to Sir Iohn Berkley at Teverton.
body.p:
YOu will, I preÅ¿ume, receive notice by Collonel Froad, before this will be with you, of the difaÅ¿ter that happened to us this day, by negligence of â¢ ome of our HorÅ¿e, which were beaten off their Guards, and perÅ¿ued by the Enemy to VVeymouth; VVhereupon a hundred Muskettiers were drawn out of VVeymouth to relieve them, which the Enemy in Melcombe, taking all advantage of, made a Å¿ally over the Draw-bridge, and have Å¿urprized the Chappell Fort, but the two principall Forts, where our ProviÅ¿ions and Ammunition lyes wee Å¿till maintaine, and doubt not by Gods aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance to keep them Å¿till, hoping that this misfortune will turne to our advantage, and bee a meanes that wee Å¿hall gaine both the Towne and Fort together. Whereupon my Lord Goring hath Å¿et up his reÅ¿t to goe through with it, being confident of your Å¿peedy aÅ¿Å¿iÅ¿tance in a worke of that infinite importance to his MajeÅ¿ties Å¿ervice; and in caÅ¿e Waller Å¿hould draw this way, which is not probable, yet your Å¿trength united with my Lords, will be much Å¿uperiour to VVallers, Å¿o as doubtleÅ¿Å¿e, wee may fight with him upon advantage, for Kell. Digby came this night to Sherborne from Oxford, who aÅ¿Å¿ured mee that EÅ¿sex and MantheÅ¿ters Forces have abÅ¿olutely left him, and that he hath not a conÅ¿iderable party with him, his Army being utterly broken, Å¿o that this place being taken, which we are confident cannot bee a worke of many dayes, the WeÅ¿t is not only Å¿ecured thereby, but my Lord Goring will
likewiÅ¿e have an opportunity of advancing into the AÅ¿Å¿ociated Counties, which are now left naked: And there is order likewiÅ¿e taken, that two thouÅ¿and HorÅ¿e from Oxford and the Vize, Å¿hall be ready to attend VVallers motion, Å¿o Å¿hall by Gods bleÅ¿Å¿ing our game goe faire, if not mar'd in the playing.

div.head: Touching the taking of Cardigan CaÅ¿tle and Town.

body.head: An Extract out of a Letter Written by Captaine William Smith, to the Lord high Admirall, from aboard the Ship called the Swallow in Milford Haven, Dated the 5. of February, 1644.
body.p:
AFter many great raines which have fallen in theÅ¿e parts (which was no invitation for a Souldier to lye in the nelds) yet Å¿uch was the gallantry of Major Generall Laugherne to promote the CauÅ¿e in hand, that the Almightie no Å¿ooner crowned his deÅ¿ires with a happy Å¿eaÅ¿on, but in a gracefull acknowledgement, hee placed a GarriÅ¿on in Laugherne CaÅ¿tle, and from thence marched towards Cardigan, with about five hundred HorÅ¿e, and three hundred Foot; and on the 21 of December, 1644. hee Å¿ate downe before Cardigan CaÅ¿tle, demanding a Å¿urrender thereof for the Å¿ervice of the King and Parliament: But Major Slaughter who commanded in chiefe, replyed, he held that CaÅ¿tle for the
Å¿ervice of the King, and Å¿o long as he had life he would keepe it for his MajeÅ¿ty, (though therein he was not a man of his word.) After three dayes Å¿iege, the Major Generall perceiving all further attempts would be in vaine, unleÅ¿Å¿e a breach could be forced, and having no artillery with him he forthwith gave order the Demy-Culverin Å¿hould be brought from Laugherne, which with much difficulty and induÅ¿try came Å¿afe to Cardigan, and being placed to the beÅ¿t advantage he fell to battery.

The enemy within the CaÅ¿tle-yard caÅ¿t up a halfe moone Å¿ome diÅ¿tance from the place on which the Demy-Culverin played, in which they placed their great gunnes laden with CaÅ¿e-Shot, that in caÅ¿e a breach Å¿hould be made thoÅ¿e guns might diÅ¿animate our men in entering, or performe Å¿uddaine execution on them: Our men plying the Demy-Culverin forced a breach, and being full of reÅ¿olution entred, running in the mouth of their guns, recovered the halfe moone, where the enemy, as men bereft of all Å¿enÅ¿e, having not the power to give fire to their guns, although the LinÅ¿tocks were in their hands ready lighted, caÅ¿t downe all their armes, and cryed for quarter, the which was granted: from thence we entred the CaÅ¿tle and tooke PriÅ¿oner Major Slaughter and his wife, one Captain Vaughan with their Lievtenant and EnÅ¿igne, one Doctor Taylor a Divine with about an hundred Common Souldiers, Å¿ix great guns, a hundred and fifty armes, a quantity of powder, ball, and other proviÅ¿ions, and this was done the 29. of December laÅ¿t. On the fourth of Ianuary, Generall Gerrard Å¿et downe before the CaÅ¿tle with about 1200 horÅ¿e and 1300. foote; Major Generall Laugherne recruted his forces to about 600. horÅ¿e, and 300. foot, and advanced towards Cardigan to redeeme his friends, who were in the
CaÅ¿tle out of the power of the Enemy; Lievtenant Collonell Powell in the night Å¿ent a Souldier who Å¿wume through the river, and informed Major Generall Laugherne, that unleÅ¿Å¿e he could releive the CaÅ¿tle, within eight dayes, he Å¿hould be enforced to Å¿urrender it for want of victualls, and ammunition, which he beleeved might be Å¿upplied, if Å¿ome Å¿eam â¢ n verÅ¿ed in managing a water fight, and climing up rocks were employed; So 120. Seamen were Å¿ent, who after a view had of the place, undertooke it, which was performed on this wiÅ¿e: A boate laden with proviÅ¿ions was placed in the middle between foure boats on each Å¿ide, two of which were manned with Seamen, who in flankes faced both wayes, plying their Musketts on the enemy, who from the Å¿hore played on them with about 300. Musketiers, yet our Seamen gallantly proceeded, put all the proviÅ¿ions into the CaÅ¿tle, and returned without the loÅ¿Å¿e of one man onely two Å¿lightly wounded. After this Collonel Laugherne having drawn his foot into a body, being without Seamen in all about 350 he encouraged them to give an aÅ¿Å¿ult on the Towne, which after Å¿ome debate was attempted, and on the 22. of January laÅ¿t our foote forced their paÅ¿Å¿age over the Bridge, in which we loÅ¿t but one man and having beaten the Enemy from their firÅ¿t guard, they preÅ¿Å¿ed on to the Å¿econd, which they alÅ¿o tooke, and purÅ¿uing the victory beate them out of their maine guard, which was at the market place, and then out of the Church, where our Forces tooke two braÅ¿Å¿e Demy-Culverins, which Gerrard brought from BriÅ¿toll, with Å¿ome Powder, Ball, and all their proviÅ¿ions, and following the enemy beat them all out of the Towne, and Å¿o we are now MaÅ¿ters both of the Towne and CaÅ¿tle. Of the enemy were Å¿laine in the place, 85. beÅ¿ides thoÅ¿e that were Å¿laine before the CaÅ¿tle, 100. priÅ¿oners were taken, and their whole Forces routed,
and I believe in their flight they never looked behind them, untill they came to CaÅ¿tle Emlyne, which is Å¿ix miles from Cardigan: In the Town we alÅ¿o took 250. armes I have not heard Å¿ince theÅ¿e unhappy differences begun in this Kingdome, that the hand of the Almighty hath more viÅ¿ibly appeared in giving Å¿o great victories to Å¿o Å¿mall a handfull then hath been manifeÅ¿ted in theÅ¿e parts, and to his own power we attribute all the praiÅ¿e and glory.

div.head: Die Martis 4. Martii, 1644.
div.p: REÅ¿olved upon the QueÅ¿tion by the Commons AÅ¿Å¿embled in Parliament; That Publique Thankes Å¿hall be given unto God for his great Mercy and bleÅ¿sing upon the Parliament Forces, in the regaining of VVeymouth, the gaining of Shrewsbury, and Scarborough, the late deliverance at Plymouth, and the great Victory over the Forces under Sir Iohn VVinter.
ReÅ¿olved upon the QueÅ¿tion,
That WedneÅ¿day come Å¿even-night (being the 12. of this preÅ¿ent March, be appointed for this day of publique ThankÅ¿giving.

Ordered that the Lord Major of the Citie of London be deÅ¿ired to give notice of this day of publique ThankÅ¿giving, to all the MiniÅ¿ters within the Lines of Communication, that they may give notice of it to their PariÅ¿hioners in their Pulpits on the next Lords day.

closer.signed: H. ElÅ¿ynge Cler. Parl. D. Com.

div.head: Die Martis 4. Martii, 1644.
div.p: IT is this day Ordered by the Lords in Parliament, That the Lord Major of the City of London, and his Brethren be deÅ¿ired to bee at the ThankeÅ¿giving on the 12. of this inÅ¿tant, in ChriÅ¿t Church, London, where the Members of both HouÅ¿es have appointed to meet to praiÅ¿e God for his bleÅ¿sing to the Parliament, for the good Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e at Shrewsbury and Weymouth. And that the Church be kept empty for the Lords and Commons.

div.head: The ConcluÅ¿ion.
div.p: ANd now Å¿ince the Arme and Power of God hath Å¿o plainly appeared; and a fire is come downe from Heaven into the hearts of thoÅ¿e that fought for Gods CauÅ¿e, to inflame them with zeale and courage, by which fire alÅ¿o their AdverÅ¿aries have been conÅ¿umed; Let the people no longer halt between two opinions, but confeÅ¿Å¿e as in the dayes of Eliah, That the Lord is God, and let it be Å¿een, That God at laÅ¿t hath turned the heart of this people. Let them no longer fight againÅ¿t God; for who ever fought againÅ¿t him and proÅ¿pered? HowÅ¿oever let Gods own people, behold and magnifie the worke of God, and let their hearts be lifted up in dependance upon him, and in the maintenance of that CauÅ¿e which he Å¿o manifeÅ¿tly owneth. Who is wiÅ¿e, and he Å¿hall underÅ¿tand theÅ¿e things? Prudent, and he Å¿hall know them; for the wayes of the Lord are right, and the juÅ¿t Å¿hall walke in them, but the tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿ors Å¿hall fall therein.
